channel.title: Comments on: What is the public evidence surrounding the latest Sci-Hub allegations?

item.title: By: Federico
item.dc:creator: Federico
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/what-is-the-public-evidence-surrounding-the-latest-sci-hub-allegations/#comment-4883">ann viera</a>.
There is no reason to believe that giving the password to Sci-Hub "leaves your institution open to security breach", unless of course you would equally classify as a "security breach" a scenario like "your spouse uses your password to download an article from home", which may technically be correct but is not what most people understand. It's not a security breach from the user's perspective when the user's account is used in the way the user expected.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to ann viera.

There is no reason to believe that giving the password to Sci-Hub “leaves your institution open to security breach”, unless of course you would equally classify as a “security breach” a scenario like “your spouse uses your password to download an article from home”, which may technically be correct but is not what most people understand. It’s not a security breach from the user’s perspective when the user’s account is used in the way the user expected.

item.title: By: protohedgehog

item.content:encoded:
In reply to ann viera.

Hear hear, thanks for this comment, Ann!

item.title: By: Daniel Spichtinger
item.dc:creator: Daniel Spichtinger
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/what-is-the-public-evidence-surrounding-the-latest-sci-hub-allegations/#comment-4883">ann viera</a>.
well put!

item.title: By: ann viera
item.dc:creator: ann viera
item.description:
Dear researchers: Don't do this. From post above: "I know a number of academics who share their login details (i.e., privileged access) with other researchers around the world to help provide them access to journals." It leaves your institution open to security breach.
Almost all institutions have mandatory security training, and not sharing login credentials is a part of that training. Almost all institutions now have two-factor authentication, so even if you share your credentials, the two-factor authentication will not allow access.
If you want access, if you are "the number of researchers frustrated at the behaviours of the private publishing sector," then don't use Sci-hub after signing away copyright. Here are some suggestions: 1) publish in an innovative affordable journal like PeerJ, and 2) self-archive your own work upon acceptance. Use Sherpa Romeo to find out what the publisher allows, without further negotiation. Talk to your scholarly communication librarian and keep careful track of versions of manuscripts so it will be easy to find the version that the publisher allows you to self-archive. 3) don't sign away your copyright 4) don't use the impact factor or confuse journal brand with quality, it is the quality of the individual work that is important.
item.content:encoded:
Dear researchers: Don’t do this. From post above: “I know a number of academics who share their login details (i.e., privileged access) with other researchers around the world to help provide them access to journals.”
It leaves your institution open to security breach.

Almost all institutions have mandatory security training, and not sharing login credentials is a part of that training. Almost all institutions now have two-factor authentication, so even if you share your credentials, the two-factor authentication will not allow access.

If you want access, if you are “the number of researchers frustrated at the behaviours of the private publishing sector,” then don’t use Sci-hub after signing away copyright. Here are some suggestions: 1) publish in an innovative affordable journal like PeerJ, and 2) self-archive your own work upon acceptance. Use Sherpa Romeo to find out what the publisher allows, without further negotiation. Talk to your scholarly communication librarian and keep careful track of versions of manuscripts so it will be easy to find the version that the publisher allows you to self-archive. 3) don’t sign away your copyright 4) don’t use the impact factor or confuse journal brand with quality, it is the quality of the individual work that is important.
